channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Salvadoran General Accused in Killings Should Be Deported, Miami Judge Says
item.description: Gen. José Guillermo García is accused of participating in the assassination of an archbishop and the massacre of over 1,000 peasants in El Salvador at a time when Washington was supporting the country’s military.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: Gen. José Guillermo García left a Florida court in 2000.

item.title: China Takes on Big Risks in Its Push for Shale Gas
item.description: While China is eager to wean itself from energy imports and coal, its extraction of shale gas is likely to be more expensive and dangerous than elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Huge drilling projects can be seen embedded into farm land outside of Fuling, China. Shale gas has been discovered in the region.

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: New Energy Strategy Approved
item.description: Japan’s cabinet approved a new national energy strategy on Friday that designates nuclear power as an important energy source and calls for restarting idled nuclear plants that meet new safety standards.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Taliban Factions Clash
item.description: Clashes this week between competing factions of the Pakistani Taliban in northwest Pakistan left more than 20 fighters dead, intelligence officials and militant commanders said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: China: Chemical Found in City’s Water
item.description: Chinese authorities have turned off the water supply to a district in the northwestern city of Lanzhou after excessive levels of a toxic chemical were found in tap water.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: American Ends Hunger Strike
item.description: Alan P. Gross, an American contractor imprisoned in Cuba, ended a hunger strike on Friday after eight days of protesting his treatment by the Cuban and United States governments.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Pope Takes Responsibility in Priests’ Abuse Scandal
item.description: Victims’ advocates complained that the unprecedented public statement of papal contrition over the scandal is still just “talk.”
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Mystery Surrounds Death of Fiery Ukrainian Activist
item.description: Oleksandr Muzychko’s gun-waving tactics and anger, largely directed against Russia, won him both admirers and enemies.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in Barmaky, Ukraine, marks where Oleksandr Muzychko of the Right Sector group died. A government report said that he shot himself.

item.title: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras Are Among the Recipients of the Polk Award
item.description: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras revealed the findings of the former government contractor Edward J. Snowden.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA and NOAM COHEN
item.media:credit: Brian Harkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras arrived in New York on Friday to accept the prestigious Polk Award for national security reporting.

item.title: Pro-Russia Ukrainians Are Promised More Power, but Remain Dubious
item.description: Ukraine’s acting prime minister abandoned threats to forcibly evict pro-Russian demonstrators from government buildings.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian demonstrators inside the administrative building on Friday in Donetsk, Ukraine.

item.title: Cups With Hitler’s Image Are Investigated in Germany
item.description: Prosecutors in Dortmund, Germany, are looking into how the image of Adolf Hitler came to appear on cups sold at a chain of stores.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Cups bearing a stamp that depicts Adolf Hitler were sold in Germany.

item.title: World Briefing: 2 Kenyans Kidnapped in Somalia in 2011 Are Found Alive
item.description: The African Union Mission in Somalia said that the two men, who were working for aid agencies, were rescued in an operation near Somalia’s border with Kenya.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: U.S. Says Iran’s Pick for U.N. Envoy Won’t Get a Visa
item.description: The administration made its position clear after Congress passed a bill to block Iran’s nominee, who participated in the 1979 Tehran hostage crisis.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Police Clash With Squatters in Rio de Janeiro Slum
item.description: The violence, which erupted when officers removed thousands of people from a newly built favela, came just weeks before the World Cup of soccer.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Police officers used tear gas against thousands of squatters, trying to evict them from the newly built Telerj Favela on Friday.

item.title: Iran Secretly Convicted Former Marine, Lawyer Says
item.description: The lawyer said his client, Amir Hekmati of Michigan, might be freed after serving three years of his 10-year term, which would be in August.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: India Ink: Incendiary Words in Campaigns Draw Ban on Rallies for Two Politicians
item.description: The Indian Election Commission determined the men made “highly inflammatory speeches” that violated its rules.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR and VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: Azam Khan, left, a cabinet minister in the Uttar Pradesh state government, with Mulayam Singh Yadav, president of the Samajwadi party, during a public rally in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, on March 2.

item.title: Diplomat Who Led Secret Talks With Iran Plans to Retire
item.description: William J. Burns’s decision to wait until October to step down as deputy secretary of state raised the possibility that he may again play a role on Iran nuclear policy should formal negotiations fall short.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: The Lede: Pope’s Request for Abuse Victims to Forgive Church Draws Calls for Action
item.description: Pope Francis said he was personally asking for forgiveness for the damage done to children.
item.category: Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Israeli Military Takes Over Seminary in West Bank Settlement
item.description: Troops moved in after radical settlers clashed with soldiers and destroyed army property at the Od Yosef Chai Yeshiva in the Jewish settlement of Yitzhar.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 11
item.description: A mustard field on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A boy riding his bicycle through a mustard field on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: Memo From Afghanistan: For Afghan Journalists, Election Brings a Sense of National Duty
item.description: A news media known for its no-holds-barred criticism has decided to focus on the positive to help foster confidence in the democratic process.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HABIB ZAHORI
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local television journalists at Zalmay Rassoul's campaign office in Kabul on election day.

item.title: Irish Republican Ordered Held Without Bail in 1998 Bombing Case
item.description: Seamus Daly has been charged with the murders of 29 people in a car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Abdellah Taïa Makes His Directorial Debut
item.description: For the author Abdellah Taïa, a Moroccan, being gay has been a source of both torment and inspiration.
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI
item.media:credit: Lauren Fleishman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdellah Taia at his home in Paris.

item.title: Turkish Court Overturns Part of Law on Judiciary, Loosening Government’s Grip
item.description: The Constitutional Court overturned a provision that gave the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan greater control over the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: In France, a Move to Limit Off-the-Clock Work Emails
item.description: A deal between unions and corporate representatives would cover hundreds of thousands of workers at consulting, computing and polling companies.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
